intro: Cola cabindensis, commonly known as the African cola nut, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is native to tropical regions of Africa, particularly the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Cameroon. The plant is characterized by its large, palmately lobed leaves and produces clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers. The fruit is a capsule that contains several hard, brown seeds, which are the source of the stimulant compound caffeine. It is often cultivated for its seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a source of caffeine in beverages.
